Title: Amylolytic process
Description: Amylolytic process or amylolysis is the conversion of starch into sugar by the action of acids or enzymes such as amylase

Title: Basting
Description: Periodically pouring liquid over food as it roasts.

Title: Brine
Description: To soak a food item in salted water.

Title: Canning
Description: Canning is a method of food preservation in which food is processed and sealed in an airtight container

Title: Cheesemaking
Description: The craft of making cheese.

Title: Curdling
Description: The breaking of an emulsion or colloid into large parts of different composition through the physico-chemical processes of flocculation, creaming, and coalescence. Curdling is intentional and desirable in making cheese and tofu, but may be unintentional and undesirable in making other foods such as sauces and custards.

Title: Fermentation
Description: In food processing, fermentation is the conversion of carbohydrates to alcohol or organic acids using microorganisms—yeasts or bacteria—under anaerobic (oxygen-free) conditions

Title: Maceration
Description: Maceration is the process of preparing foods through the softening or breaking into pieces using a liquid.

Title: Marination
Description: The technique of soaking a food in a seasoned, often acidic, liquid (known as a marinade) prior to cooking. Marination is generally used as a means of adding or enhancing flavor or tenderizing tough cuts of meat, and the process can vary greatly in duration. It is similar to but distinct from brining and pickling.

Title: Pre-ferment
Description: A ferment (also known as bread starter) is a fermentation starter used in indirect methods of bread making. It may also be called mother dough.

Title: Souring
Description: Souring is a food preparation technique that causes a physical and chemical change in food by exposing it to an acid.

Title: Spherification
Description: Spherification is a culinary process that employs sodium alginate and either calcium chloride or calcium glucate lactate to shape a liquid into squishy spheres, which visually and texturally resemble roe.

Title: Steeping
Description: Steeping is the soaking of an organic solid, such as leaves, in a liquid (usually water) to extract flavours or to soften it.

Title: Velveting
Description: A technique which involves coating pieces of raw meat or poultry in a mixture of cornstarch and liquid prior to cooking, frequently used in Chinese cuisine.

Title: Acidulated water
Description: To use an acid (such as that found in citrus juice, vinegar, or wine) to prevent browning, alter flavour, or make an item safe for canning

Title: Pickling
Description: Pickling is the process of preserving or extending the shelf life of food by either anaerobic fermentation in brine or immersion in vinegar.

Title: Anti-griddle
Description: A kitchen appliance that flash freezes or semi-freezes foods placed on its chilled metal top.

Title: Aspic
Description: A savoury gelatin made from meat stock or consommé, and often shaped in a mold

Title: Al dente
Description: To cook food (typically pasta) to the point where it is tender but not mushy.

Title: Au jus
Description: Foods served au jus, typically meat or sandwiches, are served with an unthickened sauce made from roast meat drippings, commonly in a separate side dish.

Title: Backwoods cooking
Description: A method of cooking without the use of utensils that commonly takes place in remote areas, often in combination with wild or conventional camping.

Title: Baghaar
Description: A cooking technique used in Pakistani cuisine and Indian cuisine in which cooking oil is heated and spices are added to fry. The oil is then added to a dish for flavoring.

Title: Bain-marie
Description: A method of cooking where a container of food is placed in or above boiling water in order to heat gradually or to keep warm.

Title: Baking
Description: Baking is a method of preparing food that uses dry heat, typically in an oven, but can also be done in hot ashes, or on hot stones

Title: Barbecuing
Description: Cooking meat or fish slowly over a barbecue grill with indirect heat and smoke.

Title: Barbecuing
Description: the more direct application of heat, grilling of food over hot coals or gas.This technique is usually done over direct, dry heat or a hot fire for a few minutes

Title: Blanching
Description: A technique by which a fresh food such as a vegetable or fruit is briefly immersed in boiling water, removed after a timed interval, and then plunged into iced water or rinsed with cold running water (shocking or refreshing) to halt the cooking process.

Title: Boiling
Description: Boiling is the method of cooking food in boiling water or other water-based liquids such as stock or milk.Simmering is gentle boiling, while in poaching the cooking liquid moves but scarcely bubbles.

Title: Braising
Description: A combination-cooking method that uses both wet and dry heats: typically, the food is first seared at a high temperature, then finished in a covered pot at a lower temperature while sitting in some (variable) amount of liquid (which may also add flavor).

Title: Bricolage
Description: The preparation of a meal from whatever ingredients happen to be on hand.

Title: Broasting
Description: Broasting is a method of cooking chicken and other foods using a pressure fryer

Title: Browning
Description: The process of partially cooking the surface of meat to help remove excessive fat and to give the meat a brown color crust and flavor through various browning reactions.

Title: Candy making
Description: The preparation of candies and sugar confections by dissolving sugar in water or milk to form a syrup, which is boiled until it reaches the desired concentration or starts to caramelize.

Title: Caramelization
Description: The browning of sugar, a process used extensively in cooking for the resulting nutty flavor and brown color.

Title: Carryover cooking
Description: The phenomenon by which food retains heat and continues to cook even after being removed from the source of heat.[8]

Title: Casserole
Description: Food cooked and served in a casserole dish.

Title: Char broiler
Names: Char broiler, char broiling, char broil, charcoal broil
Description: A cooking device consisting of a series of grates or ribs that can be heated using a variety of means, and is used in both residential and commercial applications for a variety of cooking operations.

Title: Coddling
Description: Heating food in water kept just below the boiling point. Coddled egg may be prepared using this method.

Title: Confit
Description: A generic term for various kinds of food that have been cooked in grease, oil, or sugar water (syrup).

Title: Consommé
Description: A type of clear soup made from richly flavored stock or bouillon that has been clarified.

Title: Creaming
Description: In baking, it is the blending of ingredients with a softened form of a solid fat. When a dish is described as being "creamed", it may mean that it has been poached in milk, cream or a similar liquid. "Creaming" can also refer to the separation of cream from milk.

Title: Croquette
Description: A small roll made of finely chopped meat and/or vegetables that is breaded and fried.

Title: Culinary triangle
Description: A concept described by anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss involving three types of cooking: boiling, roasting, and smoking, usually done to meat.

Title: Deep frying
Names: deep frying, deep fry, deep fried
Description: A technique by which a food is completely submerged in hot fat or oil (as opposed to ordinary frying, which involves placing the food in a shallow pool of oil).

Title: Deglazing
Description: Deglazing is a cooking technique for removing and dissolving browned food residue from a pan to flavor sauces, soups, and gravies.

Title: Dry roasting
Description: Dry roasting is a process by which heat is applied to dry foodstuffs without the use of oil or water as a carrier.

Title: Dum pukht
Description: A cooking technique associated with the Awadh region of India, in which meat and vegetables are cooked over a very low flame, generally in sealed containers.

Title: Dutch oven
Description: A Dutch oven is well suited for long, slow cooking, such as in making roasts, stews, and casseroles.

Title: Earth oven
Description: A shallow pit in the ground used to trap heat and bake, smoke, or steam food.

Title: En vessie
Description: A cooking method by which a meat or other dish is cooked inside an animal bladder, often a pig bladder.

Title: Engastration
Description: A cooking method by which the cook stuffs the remains of one animal into another animal

Title: Engine cooking
Description: Cooking food from the excess heat of an internal combustion engine, typically the engine of a car or a truck.

Title: Flambé
Description: To pour alcohol over food and then ignite.

Title: Flattop grill
Description: A flattop grill is a cooking appliance that resembles a griddle but performs differently because the heating element is circular rather than straight

Title: Fondue
Description: Fondue is a Swiss melted cheese dish served in a communal pot (caquelon or fondue pot) over a portable stove (réchaud) heated with a candle or spirit lamp, and eaten by dipping bread into the cheese using long-stemmed forks.

Title: Fricassee
Description: Fricassee is a stew made with pieces of meat that have been browned in butter that are served in a sauce flavored with the cooking stock

Title: Frying
Description: Frying is the cooking of food in oil or another fat.

Title: Gentle frying
Description: Gentle frying or low-temperature frying is an oil- or fat-based cooking method used for relatively fragile or starchy foods

Title: Grilling
Names: Grilling, grill, grilled, open flame grilling
Description: Grilling is a form of cooking that involves dry heat applied to the surface of food, commonly from above, below or from the side

Title: Hāngi
Description: A traditional New Zealand Māori method of cooking food using heated rocks buried in a pit oven still used for special occasions.

Title: Hibachi
Description: The hibachi is a traditional Japanese heating device. It is a brazier which is either round, cylindrical, or box-shaped, open-topped container, made from or lined with a heatproof material and designed to hold burning charcoal.

Title: High-altitude cooking
Description: The process of cooking a food or beverage at altitudes well above sea level, where lower atmospheric pressure causes most foods to cook more slowly and may necessitate the use of special cooking techniques.

Title: Hot salt frying
Description: Hot salt frying is an old cooking technique, and is used in villages throughout Asia and other parts of the world. Many foods are fried with hot salt or sand, even in common households.

Title: Huff paste
Description: Huff paste was a cooking technique involved making a stiff pie shell or coffyn using a mixture of flour, suet, and boiling water.

Title: Indirect grilling
Description: Indirect grilling is a barbecue cooking technique in which the food is placed to the side of or above the heat source instead of directly over the flame as is more common

Title: Karaage
Description: A Japanese cooking technique in which various foods — most often chicken, but also other meat and fish — are deep fried in oil, similar to the preparation of tempura.

Title: Kho
Description: A cooking technique in Vietnamese cuisine in which a protein source such as fish, shrimp, poultry, pork, beef, or fried tofu is braised on low heat in a mixture of fish sauce, sugar, and water or a water substitute such as young coconut juice. It is similar to stew.

Title: Kinpira
Description: A Japanese cooking style that can be summarized as a technique of "sauté and simmer". It is commonly used to cook root vegetables and other foods.

Title: Lardon
Description: long strips of chilled pork fat are threaded (with the use of a needle) into meats that are to be braised or roasted, such as beef filets or veal, poultry, and lean fish such as tuna.

Title: Low-temperature cooking
Description: Low-temperature cooking is a cooking technique using temperatures in the range of about 45 to 82 °C (113 to 180 °F) for a prolonged time to cook food.

Title: Microwave oven
Description: The cooking of food in a microwave oven.

Title: Mongolian barbecue
Description: Meat and vegetables are cooked on large, round, solid iron griddles at temperatures of up to 300 °C (572 °F)

Title: Nixtamalization
Description: A process for the preparation of maize (corn) or other grain in which the grain is soaked and cooked in an alkaline solution, usually limewater, and then hulled.

Title: Pan frying
Description: Characterized by the use of minimal cooking oil or fat (as opposed to shallow frying or deep frying), typically using just enough oil to lubricate the pan.

Title: Parboiling
Description: Parboiling (or leaching) is the partial or semi boiling of food as the first step in cooking.

Title: Pasteurization
Description: Pasteurization or pasteurisation is a process in which packaged and non-packaged foods (such as milk and fruit juice) are treated with mild heat, usually to less than 100 °C (212 °F), to eliminate pathogens and extend shelf life.

Title: Pig roast
Description: A pig roast or hog roast is an event or gathering which involves the barbecuing of a whole pig.

Title: Poaching
Description: Poaching is a cooking technique that involves heating food submerged in a liquid, such as water, milk, stock or wine.

Title: Pressure cooking
Description: The process of cooking food, using water or other cooking liquid, in a sealed vessel known as a pressure cooker, which does not permit air or liquids to escape below a pre-set pressure.

Title: Pressure frying
Description: pressure frying is a variation on pressure cooking where meat and cooking oil are brought to high temperatures while pressure is held high enough to cook the food more quickly.

Title: Proofing
Description: In cooking, proofing (also called proving) is a step in the preparation of yeast bread and other baked goods where the dough is allowed to rest and rise a final time before baking. During this rest period, yeast ferments the dough and produces gases, thereby leavening the dough.

Title: Reduction
Description: In cooking, reduction is the process of thickening and intensifying the flavor of a liquid mixture such as a soup, sauce, wine, or juice by simmering or boiling.

Title: Roasting
Description: Roasting is a cooking method that uses dry heat where hot air covers the food, cooking it evenly on all sides with temperatures of at least 150 °C (300 °F) from an open flame, oven, or other heat source

Title: Robatayaki
Description: In Japanese cuisine, robatayaki often shortened to robata refers to a method of cooking, similar to barbecue in which items of food are cooked at varying speeds over hot charcoal

Title: Rotisserie
Description: Rotisserie, also known as spit-roasting, is a style of roasting where meat is skewered on a spit – a long solid rod used to hold food while it is being cooked over a fire in a fireplace or over a campfire, or roasted in an oven.

Title: Roux
Description: A paste-like thickening agent made of equal quantities of flour and fat cooked together to a sandy texture.

Title: Sauteing
Description: Sautéing or sauteingis a method of cooking that uses a relatively small amount of oil or fat in a shallow pan over relatively high heat

Title: Schwenker
Description: A Schwenker is a grill on which the Schwenker steak typically is grilled.

Title: Searing
Description: A technique used in grilling, baking, braising, roasting, sautéing, etc., in which the surface of the food (usually meat, poultry, or fish) is cooked at high temperature until a crust forms from browning.

Title: Shallow frying
Description: Shallow frying is a hot oil-based cooking technique. It is typically used to prepare portion-sized cuts of meat, fish, potatoes and patties such as fritters.

Title: Shirred eggs
Description: Shirred eggs, also known as baked eggs, are eggs that have been baked in a flat-bottomed dish;

Title: Simmering
Description: Simmering is a food preparation technique by which foods are cooked in hot liquids kept just below the boiling point of water[1] (lower than 100 °C or 212 °F) and above poaching temperature (higher than 71–80 °C or 160-180 °F)

Title: Slow cooker
Description: electrical cooking appliance used to simmer at a lower temperature than other cooking methods, such as baking, boiling, and frying.

Title: Smoking
Description: Smoking is the process of flavoring, browning, cooking, or preserving food by exposing it to smoke from burning or smoldering material, most often wood.

Title: Smothering
Description: The technique involves cooking in a covered pan over low heat with a moderate amount of liquid, and can be regarded as a form of stove-top braising.

Title: Sous-vide
Description: Sous vide also known as low temperature long time (LTLT) cooking, is a method of cooking in which food is placed in a plastic pouch or a glass jar and cooked in a water bath for longer than usual cooking times (usually 1 to 7 hours, up to 72 or more hours in some cases) at a precisely regulated temperature.

Title: Steaming
Description: Steaming is a method of cooking using steam.

Title: Stewing
Description: A stew is a combination of solid food ingredients that have been cooked in liquid and served in the resultant gravy.

Title: Stir frying
Description: Stir frying is a Chinese cooking technique in which ingredients are fried in a small amount of very hot oil while being stirred or tossed in a wok.

Title: Sweating
Description: The gentle heating of vegetables in a little oil or butter, which usually results in tender, sometimes translucent, pieces.

Title: Tandoor
Description: The heat for a tandoor was traditionally generated by a charcoal or wood fire, burning within the tandoor itself, thus exposing the food to live fire, radiant heat cooking, and hot-air, convection cooking, and smoking in the fat and food juices that drip on to the charcoal.

Title: Teriyaki
Description: Teriyaki is a cooking technique used in Japanese cuisine in which foods are broiled or grilled with a glaze of soy sauce, mirin, and sugar.

Title: Thermal immersion circulator
Description: Uses the concept of the haybox whereby placing hay or straw around a cooking pot of heated food the meal continues to cook without fuel.

Title: Thickening
Description: add thickner or simmering untill the water evaporates and gravy thickens

Title: Turkey fryer
Description: A turkey fryer is an apparatus for deep-frying a turkey

Title: Wok chi
Description: Woks are used in a range of Chinese cooking techniques, including stir frying, steaming, pan frying, deep frying, poaching, boiling, braising, searing, stewing, making soup, smoking and roasting nuts

Title: Curing
Description: Food preserved by fermentation, pickling, smoking, or some combination of these techniques.

Title: Parbaking
Description: Parbaking is a cooking technique in which a bread or dough product is partially baked and then rapidly frozen for storage

Title: Rillettes
Description: Rillettes is a preservation method similar to confit where meat is seasoned then slow cooked submerged in fat and cooked at an extremely slow rate for several hours (4 to 10 hours)

Title: Amandine
Description: Amandine, sometimes Anglicised as almondine, is a culinary term indicating a garnish of almonds. Dishes of this sort are usually cooked with butter and seasonings, then sprinkled with whole or flaked, toasted almonds. The term is often spelled almondine in American cookbooks.

Title: Au gratin
Description: Gratin is a culinary technique in which an ingredient is topped with a browned crust, often using breadcrumbs, grated cheese, egg or butter.Gratin is usually prepared in a shallow dish of some kind. A gratin is baked or cooked under an overhead grill or broiler to form a golden crust on top and is often served in its baking dish.

Title: Chiffonade
Description: To cut leaves into long thin strips.

Title: Concasse
Description: To rough chop any ingredient, especially vegetables. The term is particularly applied to tomatoes, where tomato concasse is a tomato that has been peeled, seeded (seeds and skins removed), and chopped to specified dimensions.

Title: Dough sheeting
Description: A technique used in industrial bakeries that involves rolling out dough into a (consistent) dough sheet with a desired even thickness prior to baking.

Title: Dredging
Description: Coating the exterior of a food with a dry material (such as breadcrumbs) prior to cooking.

Title: Egg wash
Description: A preparation of beaten eggs, sometimes mixed with another liquid such as water or milk, which is brushed onto the surface of a pastry before baking.

Title: En papillote
Description: A technique by which a food is put into a folded pouch or parcel and then baked.

Title: Escagraph
Description: Writing made out of food.

Title: Fish fillet
Description: To remove bones from meat or fish.

Title: Foam
Description: A gelling or stabilizing agent in which air is suspended, creating a light, "fluffy" edible substance, e.g. whipped cream, meringue, and mousse.

Title: Garnish
Description: To add a decorative element to a plate of food prior to serving.

Title: Gratin
Description: Gratin is a culinary technique in which an ingredient is topped with a browned crust, often using breadcrumbs, grated cheese, egg or butter.Gratin is usually prepared in a shallow dish of some kind. A gratin is baked or cooked under an overhead grill or broiler to form a golden crust on top and is often served in its baking dish.

Title: Icing (food)
Description: glaze used on cookies or cakes

Title: Juicing
Description: Juicing is the process of extracting juice from plant tissues such as fruit or vegetables.

Title: Julienning
Description: A culinary knife cut which involves cutting food (typically vegetables) into long thin strips.

Title: Mincing
Description: Mincing is a food preparation technique in which food ingredients are finely divided into uniform pieces

Title: Purée
Description: A purée (or mash) is cooked food, usually vegetables, fruits or legumes, that has been ground, pressed, blended or sieved to the consistency of a creamy paste or liquid.

Title: Reconstituted meat
Description: The process of assembling a palatable food product from processed sources (for example, adding water to concentrated juice or forming meat slurry into chicken nuggets).

Title: Ricing
Description: Ricing is a cooking term meaning to pass food through a food mill or "ricer", which comes in several forms

Title: Separating eggs
Description: Separating eggs is a process, generally used in cooking, in which the egg yolk is removed from the egg white

Title: Shrivelling
Description: Shrivelling is a natural phenomenon where an object, with an attached sub-elastic covering, has its interior volume reduced in some way.

Title: Straight dough
Description: Straight dough is a single-mix process of making bread. The dough is made from all fresh ingredients, and they are all placed together and combined in one kneading or mixing session.

Title: Stuffing
Description: An edible food mixture, often a starch, used to fill a cavity in another food item.

Title: Sugar panning
Description: Sugar panning, or simply panning, is a method for adding a candy "shell" to candy or nuts.

Title: Swiss steak
Description: Swiss steak is a dish of meat, usually beef, that is swissed by rolling or pounding before being braised in a cooking pot of stewed vegetables and seasonings.

Title: Syringe
Description: For injecting fillings in foods.

Title: Tataki
Description: Two methods of preparing fish or meat in Japanese cuisine are called tataki or tosa-mi. In Japanese, tataki means "pounded" or "hit into pieces".

Title: Zest
Description: The colourful outer layer of citrus fruits, often scraped off and used as a flavouring ingredient.

Title: Emulsify
Description: To combine two liquids that have a natural tendency to separate (such as oil and vinegar) into one homogeneous mass.

Title: Paste
Description: A food paste is a semi-liquid colloidal suspension, emulsion, or aggregation used in food preparation or eaten directly as a spread

Title: Seasoning
Description: Seasoning is the process of adding herbs, salts or spices to food to enhance the flavour.

Title: Glaze
Description: In cooking, a glaze is a glossy, translucent coating applied to the outer surface of a dish by dipping, dripping, or using a brush.

Title: Nappage
Description: Nappage or apricot glaze is a glazing technique used in pastry making

Title: Pellicle
Description: A skin or coating of proteins on the surface of meat, fish, or poultry, which allows smoke to better adhere to the surface of the meat during the smoking process.

Title: Food drying
Description: Any of a variety of processes by which a food is preserved by removing moisture, often by the use of a modern food dehydrator or by the traditional method of allowing sunlight and fresh air to evaporate moisture.

Title: Food preservation
Description: Food preservation includes food processing practices which prevent the growth of microorganisms, such as yeasts (although some methods work by introducing benign bacteria or fungi to the food), and slow the oxidation of fats that cause rancidity.

Title: Fruit preserves
Description: Fruit preserves are preparations of fruits whose main preserving agent is sugar and sometimes acid, often stored in glass jars and used as a condiment or spread.

Title: Pascalization
Description: Pascalization, bridgmanization, high pressure processing (HPP)or high hydrostatic pressure processing is a method of preserving and sterilizing food, in which a product is processed under very high pressure, leading to the inactivation of certain microorganisms and enzymes in the food

Title: Degreasing
Description: Degreasing, often called defatting or fat trimming, is the removal of fatty acids from an object. In culinary science, degreasing is done with the intention of reducing the fat content of a meal.

Title: char grilling
Names: char grill, char grilled, char grilling

Title: Churrasco
Description: Churrasco is a Portuguese and Spanish word that refers to grilled meat, especially beef, in South American and Iberian cuisines

Title: toasting
Description: bread that has been browned to a crisp-like texture
